item.title: AMD unveils new AI PC processors for general use and gaming at CES
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Szkutak
item.description: AMD announced the latest version of its AI-powered PC chips designed for a variety of tasks from gaming to content creation and multitasking.

item.title: Microsoft’s Nadella wants us to stop thinking of AI as ‘slop’
item.dc:creator: Julie Bort
item.description: Nadella wants us to think of AI as a human helper instead of a slop-generating job killer. New data for 2026 indicates he could be right.

item.title: Nvidia wants to be the Android of generalist robotics
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bellan
item.description: Nvidia unveiled a full-stack robotics ecosystem at CES 2026, including foundation models, simulation tools, and hardware. It wants to be the default platform for robotics.

item.title: Nvidia launches powerful new Rubin chip architecture
item.dc:creator: Russell Brandom
item.description: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang officially launched the company’s new Rubin computing architecture, which he described as the state of the art in AI computing.

item.title: Nvidia launches Alpamayo, open AI models that allow autonomous vehicles to ‘think like a human’
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bellan
item.description: Nvidia unveiled Alpamayo at CES 2026, which includes a reasoning vision language action model that allows an autonomous vehicle to think more like a human and provide chain-of-thought reasoning.

item.title: CES 2026: Follow live as Nvidia, Lego, AMD, Amazon, and more make their big reveals
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Korosec, Sarah Perez
item.description: CES 2026, the annual consumer tech conference held in Las Vegas, is here. And lucky for you, we have TechCrunch editors and reporters on the ground to cover the news, scout out the interesting, weird, and relevant (and some not so relevant) tech, and of course the people working on it. Even before the official kickoff of CES on January 6, there will be product reveals from Amazon, Nvidia, Hyundai, AMD, and more. AI is at the center of most of the action. But this year, we're hearing a lot more about the convergence of AI and the physical world, whether it's in factories, robotics, or autonomous vehicles. Follow our live updates as we share all the reveals and new hardware as it happens.

item.title: Amazon’s AI assistant comes to the web with Alexa.com
item.dc:creator: Sarah Perez
item.description: Amazon is bringing Alexa+ to the web with a new Alexa.com site, expanding its AI assistant beyond devices and positioning it as a family-focused, agent-style chatbot.

item.title: Google previews new Gemini features for TV at CES 2026
item.dc:creator: Sarah Perez
item.description: Google TV will let you ask Gemini to find and edit your photos, adjust your TV settings, and more.

item.title: DoorDash says it banned driver who seemingly faked a delivery using AI
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description: DoorDash seems to have confirmed a viral story about a driver using an AI-generated photo to lie about making a delivery.

item.title: French and Malaysian authorities are investigating Grok for generating sexualized deepfakes
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description: France and Malaysia have joined India in condemning Grok for creating sexualized deepfakes of women and minors.

item.title: Plaud launches a new AI pin and a desktop meeting notetaker
item.dc:creator: Ivan Mehta
item.description: Plaud is going after the likes of Granola to launch a desktop app that records online meetings.

item.title: Subtle releases earbuds with its noise-isolation models
item.dc:creator: Ivan Mehta
item.description: Subtle's new $199 earbuds will also let you dictate in any app on desktop or phone.

item.title: Tech billionaires cashed out $16B in 2025 as stocks soared
item.dc:creator: Connie Loizos
item.description: Jeff Bezos led the way. The Amazon founder sold 25 million shares for $5.7 billion in June and July, right around the time he was getting hitched to Lauren Sánchez in Venice.

item.title: India orders Musk’s X to fix Grok over ‘obscene’ AI content
item.dc:creator: Jagmeet Singh
item.description: India's IT ministry has given X 72 hours to submit an action-taken report.

item.title: How AI is reshaping work and who gets to do it, according to Mercor’s CEO
item.dc:creator: Theresa Loconsolo
item.description: Three-year-old startup Mercor has become a $10 billion middleman in AI’s data gold rush. The company connects AI labs like OpenAI and Anthropic with former employees of Goldman Sachs, McKinsey, and white-shoe law firms, paying them up to $200 an hour to share their industry expertise and train the AI models that could eventually automate their former employers out of business.   Today we’re bringing […]

item.title: Nvidia’s AI empire: A look at its top startup investments
item.dc:creator: Marina Temkin
item.description: Over the last two years, Nvidia has used its ballooning fortunes to invest in over 100 AI startups. Here are the giant semiconductor's largest investments.

item.title: In 2026, AI will move from hype to pragmatism
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bellan
item.description: In 2026, here's what you can expect from the AI industry: new architectures, smaller models, world models, reliable agents, physical AI, and products designed for real-world use.

item.title: European banks plan to cut 200,000 jobs as AI takes hold
item.dc:creator: Connie Loizos
item.description: The bloodletting will hit hardest in back-office operations, risk management, and compliance.

item.title: OpenAI bets big on audio as Silicon Valley declares war on screens
item.dc:creator: Connie Loizos
item.description: The form factors may differ, but the thesis is the same: audio is the interface of the future. Every space -- your home, your car, even your face -- is becoming an interface.

item.title: ‘College dropout’ has become the most coveted startup founder credential
item.dc:creator: Marina Temkin
item.description: AI founders are increasingly using their "dropout" status as a credential during YC pitches.
